tn.text: This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the writer tells about a new person in the story, Adonizedek.
This is the name of a man who is an important king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of kings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Travel to where I am." Jerusalem was higher in elevation than other cities in Canaan.
"5 kings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
These are the names of cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: They set up their positions against Gibeon
tn.text: This means they set up their camp around their city. This was a way of weakening those in the city. It prevented people from escaping the city, and it prevented others from bringing food and water to them in the city.
[[:en:bible:notes:jos:00:intro]]
[[:en:bible:notes:jos:10:00]]
[[:en:bible:questions:comprehension:jos:10]]
The word "They" here refers to Gibeonites.

tn.ref: Do not withdraw your hands from your servants
tn.text: This humble request is stated with two negatives to emphasize the need for a positive action. AT: "Please come and use your strength to protect us." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
The word "hands" here refers to the people of Israel's strength. AT: "your strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: I have given them into your hand
tn.text: Here "hand" represents the people of Israel's strength and their ability to defeat their enemy. The word "them" refers to the attacking army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "them" refers to the attacking armies.
The entire army of Israel is referred to here by the name of their commander, Joshua. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Yahweh confused the enemy before Israel
tn.text: Here "Israel" refers to the entire army of Israel.
These are the names of cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: threw large stones down from heaven
tn.text: "threw large hailstones from the sky"

tn.ref: Sun, be still at Gibeon, and moon, in the Valley of Aijalon
tn.text: Joshua is praying that Yahweh would make the progression of time stop on this day. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Joshua commands the sun and moon as if these were people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Is this not written in The Book of Jashar?
tn.text: The writer uses this question as background information to remind the reader that the incident is well-documented. AT: "This is written in The Book of Jashar." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Messengers came and told Joshua. AT: "Someone told Joshua" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The phrase "your hand" here means "your control." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Translate the same way as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jos:10:09|10:10]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: No one dared to say one word against
tn.text: Here "one word" refers to the speaking of the enemies about Israel. AT: "no one dared to complain or protest against" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Open the mouth of the cave
tn.text: Here "mouth" is an idiom that means "entrance." AT: "Open the entrance of the cave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
every soldier of Israel (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"until the author wrote this story"
This is the name of a city. See how you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:jos:10:09|10:10]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: He completely destroyed them and every living creature there. He left no survivors.
tn.text: The second sentence summarizes the first sentence to emphasize that Joshua left no person or animal alive. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: gave it into the hand of Israel
tn.text: Here "hand" means "control of." AT: "gave control of it to Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These are the names of cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This phrase means "giving control to the nation of Israel." AT: "Yahweh gave Lachish into the control of the nation of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a man who is an important king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of cities.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: struck it with the sword ... completely destroyed everyone in it
tn.text: These two phrases have similar meanings. Together they show the completeness of the destruction of Eglon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This is the name of a city. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jos:10:03|10:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: They captured it and struck with the sword
tn.text: The sword represents the army of Israel and striking expresses the idea of slaughter and destruction. AT: "They captured and killed and destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: They completely destroyed every living creature in it, leaving no survivors ... He completely destroyed it, and every living creature in it.
tn.text: These two sentence are saying basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. Together they emphasize the completeness of the destruction of Hebron. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
These are the names of cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: They struck them with the sword
tn.text: The sword represents the army of Israel and striking expresses the idea of slaughter and destruction. AT: "They killed and destroyed them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Of all their kings he left not one survivor. He completely destroyed every living thing
tn.text: These two phrases share similar meanings and emphasize the complete destruction that the people of Israel accomplished at Yahweh's command. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Joshua struck them with the sword
tn.text: The sword represents the army of Israel and striking expresses the idea of slaughter and destruction. AT: "Joshua killed and destroyed them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Joshua captured all these kings and their land
tn.text: This refers to the kings and lands that were listed beginning in [[:en:bible:notes:jos:10:28|10:28]].
Here Joshua represents his whole army. AT: "Joshua and his soldiers captured" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This does not mean in one day. It means during one military campaign, which may have lasted many days or weeks.
